sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: Why, troth, and so did my aunt.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: My mother gave it him to wear.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: And your father, in his turn, to me.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: You are talking nonsense.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: I'm in the habit; for by reason of it I make a livelihood the more easily. What is the matter now?

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: I entreat you, don't be keeping me from finding my parents.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: How can I? Have I got your father and mother hidden beneath the stone? Holding up the ring.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: I was born a free woman.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: And so were many others, who are now in servitude.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: Really now, I'm vexed.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: For my part, I've told you how this came into my possession. How often must you be told? I cheated the Captain at dice, I tell you. THERAPONTIGONUS.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: eyeing CURCULIO. I'm all right; see, here he is whom I was looking for. How do you do, good sir?

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: I hear you; three casts of the dice, if you like, even for that scarf of yours.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Why don't you go to very perdition, with your casts and catch-penniesCasts and catch-pennies: "Cum bolis, cum bulbis." Literally "with your casts of dice and your onions." He probably uses the word "bulbis" solely for its similarity to "bolis," by way of alliteration. A little variation is made in the translation, to keep the spirit of the passage, which it is impossible to do by adhering to the letter.? Either give me back the money or the young woman?

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: with an air of surprise. What money? what rubbish are you talking about to me? What young woman are you demanding back of me? THER. The one that you took away this day from the Procurer, you scoundrelly fellow.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: I took none away.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Why, surely, I see her. There she is. Pointing to PLANESIUM.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: This young woman is free.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What, my female slave free, to whom I have never given her liberty?

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: Who gave you possession of her, or of whom did you buy her? Let me know that?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Why, I paid the money for her through my banker--a sum which I'll have refunded to me fourfold by you and the Procurer.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: You, who understand how to traffic in young women, kidnapped and of free birth, come you before the judge.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I shan't come.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: I may call my witnessCall my witness: It was a custom with the Romans, when a man was summoned by another to go with him at once before the Prætor, for the plaintiff, if the defendant would not go quietly, to call any bystander to be witness (antestari) that he had been duly summnened; and, having touched the ear of the witness, the latter was bound to aid in dragging the defendant to court. Only free persons could be witnesses. For this reason the Captain tells Phædromus that he cannot summon a witness on this occasion, as he knows that Planesium is not free, and supposes that Curculio is also a slave. to the summons.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: No, you mayn't.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: May Jupiter then utterly confound you: live without witnessesWithout witnesses: "Intestatus." An indelicate allusion tended in this line. then.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: But I'm a person that he may summon.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: to CURCULIO. Do you step this way.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What? A slave summoned as a witness? Take you care.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: Well, that you may know it, I'm free.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Then come before the judge. There's for you: take that. Gives him a blow.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: O townsmen, townsmen, help.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Why do you bawl so?

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: What right have you to strike him?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Because I choose.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: to CURCULIO. Step this way you pushes him towards the CAPTAIN; there, I'll give him up to you. Hold your noise.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: Phædromus, prithee do save me.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: As I would myself and my own good Genius. Captain, prithee, do tell me whence you got that ring, which this Parasite purloined from you.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: kneeling before the CAPTAIN. By your knees, I do entreat you to give us that information.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What matters that to you? You might as well ask after this sabre and this scarf, how each came into my possession.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: What airs the swaggerer does give himself!

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Send that fellow away pointing to CURCULIO; then I'll tell you all.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: It's nonsense what he says.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: Prithee, do let me know.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I'll tell you: to PLANESIUM get up. Listen to this matter, and give attention. My father Periphanes used to wear it.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: Ha! Periphanes?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: He, before he died, gave it to me as being his son, as it was right he should.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: O Jupiter!

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: And on that occasion he made me his heir.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: O filial affection, do thou preserve me, since I have carefully preserved thee. Welcome, my brother.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: How am I to believe that? Tell me, if you are speaking the truth, who was your mother?

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: Cleobula.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Who was your nurse?

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: Archestrata. Amid the sacred rites of Bacchus she had carried me to see the sights * * * * * * * after we had come thither, when now she had found me a place, a whirlwind aroseA whirlwind arose: Many mishaps appear to have happened to families through the lawlessness and violence of which the Festivals of the Divinities were the occasion.; the scaffoldingThe scaffolding: Suetonius tells us that the reign of Tiberius was rendered memorable by the fall of the scaffolding in the theatre of Fidenæ. of the stage there tumbled down; I was greatly alarmed, and then some one, I know not who, seized hold of me trembling and frightened, neither alive nor dead; and in what manner he carried me off I cannot say.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I recollect that disturbance happening; but, do you tell me, where is this person, who carried you away?

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: I know not; but showing a ring this ring I have all along preserved by me, with it long since was I lost.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Give it me to look at.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: to PLANESIUM. Are you in your senses to be trusting it to that fellow? Holds her arm.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: Do you only leave me alone. (She gives it to the CAPTAIN.)

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: examining it. O Jupiter! This is the same that I presented you upon your birthday; I recognize it as easily as my own self. Welcome to you, my sister.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: My brother, welcome to you.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: I trust the Gods will prosper this matter for you.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: And I, for all of us. To the CAPTAIN. Do you, as having this day arrived, give a dinner in honor of your sister he pointing to PHÆDROMUS, to-morrow, will give one in honor of his marriage; we promise that.

sp.speaker: PIÆD.
sp.p: to CURCULIO. Do you hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: I shan't hold my tongue, as things are turning out so well. Captain, do you promise her to him; I'll give the marriage-portion.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What is the marriage-portion?

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: What, that I give? Why, that always as long as he lives he's to feed me.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I' troth, he says what's fair; with my consent you shall do so. But this Procurer owes me the thirty minæ.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: For what reason so?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Because he agreed with me on these terms to give it back: that if any one should assert her to be free born in due course of law, he would, without dispute, pay back all the money.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: Then let's go to the Procurer.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: This first I wish; to despatch my matter.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: That you will betroth her to me. The CAPTAIN considers.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: Why do you hesitate, Captain, to give her as a wife to him?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: If she is agreable.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: My brother, it is my wish.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: So be it then.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: You do rightly.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: Captain, do you betroth me to her for my wife?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I do betroth her.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: pointing to CURCULIO. And to him do I promise support at my expense.

sp.speaker: CURCULIO
sp.p: You do kindly. But * * * * * * * *

sp.speaker: THER,
sp.p: * * * * * But see, here's the Procurer coming; my treasurerMy treasurer: In allusion to the money which he intends to have back from the Procurer. "Thesaurum" seems here to have the signification of "treasurer" or "treasury.", I mean.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: to himself. Those who sayThose who say: This and the following line are clearly in a very corrupt state. Indeed, it is hard to gather any sense whatever from them. it's bad for bankers to be trusted, utter nonsense; I say it's neither good nor bad for them to be trusted, and that, I've fully experienced this day. They are notThey are not: He seems to mean, that, where there is no possibility of the debtor paying back the money, the case is more fortunate than where you are tormented by hopes of getting it back, which, however, are doomed to disappointment. badly trusted, who never repay, but with whom it is lost outright. As for example, before this Lyco paid me the ten minæ, he had to go to every banker's counter. After there were no proceeds, I summoned the fellow with much noise; he appealed against me to the court. I was most confoundedly afraid that this day he'd be settling accounts with me before the PrætorBefore the Prætor: He was afraid that Lyco would cheat him, by filing his schedule, or taking the benefit, in the Roman style. See the Note to l. 373 (Act III., Sc. 1).; but my friends forced him, so he paid the money at home. Now I'm resolved to make haste to my house. Runs towards his door.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Hallo! you Procurer; I want you.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: And I want you.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: But I don't want either of you.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Stay this instant, will you.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: And make you haste to disgorge the money with all despatch.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: to PHÆDROMUS. What have you to do with me? To the CAPTAIN. Or what have you?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Because this day I shall be making a javelin of you, discharged from a catapulta, and twist you with the stringWith the string: "Nervus," "a cord," was also the name of the iron chain fastened round the neck and legs of the prisoner. If the debtor did not pay within thirty days after judgment, lie was liable to be thrown into prison by the creditor., just as the catapultas are in the habit of doing.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: I'll this day make a coxcomb of you, to be sleeping with a puppyWith a puppy: He jokes on the double meaning of the word "catellus," which signified "an iron chain," and also "a little dog." in your bed--an iron one, I mean.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: But I'll make you both to be rotting in a strong-barred prison.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Seize him by the throat, and away with him to extreme torture.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: However that is, he'll be going there of his own accord. The CAPTAIN seizes him.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: O Gods and men, your aid! that I, uncondemned, and without evidence against me, should thus be dragged along! Prithee, Planesium, and you, Phædromus, do give me assistance.

sp.speaker: PLANESIUM
sp.p: Brother, I do beseech you, don't ruin him uncondemned; he treated me kindly and modestly at his house.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: That was through no inclination of his own; give you thanks to this ÆsculapiusTo this Æsculapius: Who had not granted him convalescence so soon as he desired. pointing to the Temple that you've preserved your chastity; for if he had been well, he'd long ago have packed you off wherever he could.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: Now attend to me, both of you, if I can arrange between you. To the CAPTAIN. You let him go. Procurer, come you this way. I'll pronounce my opinion, if indeed you are ready to abide by what I shall decide you should do.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: We leaves it to you. He lets go of the PROCURER.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: So long, i' faith, as you give a decision to the effect that no one is to take the money away from me.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What, not that which you promised?

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: I, promised? How?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: With your tongue.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: With that same tongue I now gainsay it; that was given me by Nature for the purpose of speaking, not of losing my property.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: He's trifling; seize the fellow by the throat. Seizes him. CAP. I'll at once then do as you bid me.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Since you are an honest man, answer me this that I ask you.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: Ask me what you please.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Did you not promise, that if any one should show that she pointing to PLANESIUM was freeborn, you would pay back all the money?

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: I don't remember saying so.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What, do you deny it?

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: I' faith, I really do deny it. In whose presence? In what place was it?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: In my own presence, and that of Lyco the banker.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: Why don't you hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I shan't hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: I don't care a rush for you; don't be bullying me.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: In my own presence and that of Lyco it took place.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: to the CAPTAIN. I quite believe you. Now, therefore, Procurer, that you may know my judgment, pointing to PLANESIUM she is a free woman; he pointing to the CAPTAIN is her brother, and she is his sister; she is engaged to me; do you restore him the money; that's my decision.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: Upon my faith, Phædromus, you have given this decision corruptly. It shall both be bad for you, and you, Captain,--may the Gods and Goddesses confound you.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: And as for you, you shall be clapt in prison at once, unless the money's returned me.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: Then follow me.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Follow you where?

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: To my banker--to the PrætorTo the Prætor: See the Note to l. 684.; for it's there that I pay my money to all persons to whom I'm indebted.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I'll be carrying you hence to prison, and not to the Prætor, if you don't pay back the money.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: I do most earnestly wish you may come to a bad end, so don't misunderstand meDon't misunderstand me: "Ne me nescias." Equivalent to our phrase, "I fully give you to understand.".

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: Do you really so?

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: I' faith, I really do so.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: I don't misunderstand these fists of mine. Holding them up.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: What then, do you ask? With these same fists, if you provoke me, I'll be making you quiet immediately.

sp.speaker: CAPPADOX
sp.p: taking the money from his girdle. Well then, take this back at once.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: taking the money. By all means.

sp.speaker: PHÆD.
sp.p: Captain, you'll dine with me; the nuptials shall take place to-day.

sp.speaker: THERAPONTIGONUS
sp.p: May this matter turn out well for me and for yourselves.
Spectators, give us your applause.
